titleInfo.title: Challenging Assumptions
titleInfo.subTitle: Exploring the Extent of Biophilic Design in Interior Environments on Attention Restoration

name.namePart: Department of Interior Architecture and Design

mods:mods.abstract: The use of direct attention – one's ability to devote cognitive resources to planning, comprehension, and reflection – emerged from the adaptive need to respond and attend to environmental stimuli. The constant calls to awareness presented by entertainment technologies and urban landscapes in the modern context contributes to the issue of individuals experiencing excessive cognitive fatigue or attention deficits. Attention Restoration Theory (ART) empirically and subjectively finds that the love of connecting with the natural world, or biophilia, facilitates the restoration of directed attention. Attention Restoration Theory also presents ten properties from a person-environment perspective that distinguish experiences as restorative. However, little is known regarding how much nature exposure is beneficial for attention restoration in interior environments, leaving much to be learned about how Attention Restoration Theory manifests in practical applications like schools, offices, and hospitals. This prompts the question, to what degree do multisensory outdoor biophilic environments restore attention? To what degree do multisensory biophilic interior environments restore attention? The challenge of directed attention deficits in the world today also impacts college students. This study used a mixed methods approach to further understand the critical threshold of nature exposure needed to see a positive impact on attention spans. While this line of research requires further investigation given the small sample size, the experiment and post-test questionnaire suggest that the highest degree of nature exposure is not necessarily the most effective environmental condition to restore attention deficits. Additionally, individuals who referenced a mindfulness practice scored significantly higher in all groups, regardless of degree of nature exposure. To this effect, the confluence of study findings and existing literature review on Attention Restoration Theory, embodied cognition, and biophilic patterns offered intentional frameworks to revitalize an educational space intended for sustaining and refreshing the directed attention spans of students.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Interior Architecture and Design in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.
attention deficit, attention restoration, biophilia, environment, interior design, soft fascination
Stephanie Sickler, Professor Directing Thesis; Yelena McLane, Committee Member; Meghan Mick, Committee Member; Jill Pable, Committee Member.
